django-sanity code reference¶

Sanity framework code reference¶

sanity.management¶

sanity.management

Sane management command that runs the related tests for the environment resource passed to it.

sanity.management.commands.sane.harvest_sanity_settings()[source]¶

Reap sanity specific settings used for customizing sanity related tests.

For any configurations that you’d like to pass to django-sanity, just name space them with a ‘SANITY_’ string and put them in Django settings. This adds a great amount of flexibility to the django-sanity framework for customized testing. SANITY_CELERY_TIMEOUT is an example of how we are using this concept for a custom timeout option for tests.

Parameters:None – No args.
Returns:dict – All keyword pairs that start with ‘SANITY_’ in Django settings.
Handles :None
Raises :ValueError
class sanity.management.commands.sane.Command[source]¶
handle(*args, **options)[source]¶

Run the Django command.

Match the args to the appropriate tests and kick off the test suite runner.

sanity.toolbox¶

sanity.toolbox

Common utilities for SANE.

sanity.toolbox.get_celery_daemon_code_path(celery_daemon)[source]¶

Extract the celery worker code path from the argument and return it.

Celery workers use the -pythonpath flag to indicate that the argument following it will be a code path. This function relies on that assumption to extract the code path.

Parameters:celery_daemon (str.) – The command string used to start the celery worker.
Returns:str – The celery worker code path.
Handles :None
Raises :ValueError
sanity.toolbox.get_celery_daemon_log(celery_daemon)[source]¶

Extract the celery worker log path from the argument and return it.

Celery workers use the -f flag to indicate that the argument following it will be a log file. This function relies on that assumption to extract the log file.

Parameters:celery_daemon (str.) – The command string used to start the celery worker.
Returns:str – The celery worker log path.
Handles :ValueError
Raises :None
sanity.toolbox.get_celery_daemon_queue(celery_daemon)[source]¶

Extract the celery worker queue name from the argument and return it.

Celery workers use the -Q flag to indicate that the argument following it will be the queue that it’s using. This function relies on that assumption to extract the queue name.

Parameters:celery_daemon (str.) – The command string used to start the celery worker.
Returns:str – The celery worker queue.
Handles :ValueError
Raises :None
sanity.toolbox.get_celery_stats()[source]¶

Return a dict consisting of the Celery stats.Extract the celery queue from the argument and return it.

Use the celery.task.control api to inspect the Celery workers for stats and return them into a dict.

Parameters:None – No args.
Returns:
  • int – -1 means cannot connect to the the Rabbit MQ server.
  • str – Empty str means there are no celery workers running.
  • dict – A dict consisting of the stats.
Handles :None
Raises :timeout
sanity.toolbox.get_result_of_task(task, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Get the result of a Celery task

Wait for Celery task to complete and then pull the result from the async object.

Parameters:
  • task (str.) – The name of the Celery task.
  • args (*args) – Args to pass to the Celery task.
  • kwargs (**kwargs) – Keyword args to pass to the Celery task.
Returns:

str – The result of the task.
Handles :

None
Raises :

timeout
sanity.toolbox.get_shasum_for_current_directory()[source]¶

Get the shasum of a directory.

Use the sha1sum module to calculate the hash for the current directory. This hash will be used for comparisons to ensure that 2 or more directories have the same code.

Parameters:None – No args.
Returns:str – The shasum of the current directory.
Handles :None
Raises :A ValueError will be raised if Popen is called with invalid arguments.
sanity.toolbox.is_open(ip, port)[source]¶

..or would you prefer i use nmap?

sanity.toolbox.print_django_celery_config()[source]¶

Print the Dango Celery Config.

Loop through the Django settings file for celery related variables and then print them.

sanity.tasks

class sanity.tasks.get_cmdline[source]¶

Return the command of a pid.

Return the command of a pid. This is code will be used to get more information from the Celery workers.

Parameters:pid (str.) – Look up the command by the pid.
Returns:str – The command.
Handles :None
Raises :A ValueError will be raised if Popen is called with invalid arguments.

class sanity.tasks.get_shasum_for_celery_worker_code_path[source]¶

Get the shasum of a directory.

Use the sha1sum module to calculate the hash for the directory passed in. This hash will be used for comparisons to ensure that 2 or more directories have the same code.

Parameters:code_path (str.) – Directory to generate a shasum hash for.
Returns:str – The shasum of the directory passed in.
Handles :None
Raises :A ValueError will be raised if Popen is called with invalid arguments.

Return true.

Lightweight Celery Beat task that let’s us know it’s still alive.

Parameters:None – No args.
Returns:bool – Always return true.
Handles :None
Raises :None
class sanity.tasks.get_server[source]¶

Return server information.

Get all of the related server information from the machine that the Celery worker is runnning on.

Parameters:None – No args.
Returns:dict – host, build, port, etc.
Handles :None

Celery unit tests code reference¶

sanity.checks.celery¶

sanity.checks.celery

Home for Celery related environment tests. We look forward in the future to taking advantage of a failfast option for the test runner, which is provided by python 2.7 and greater.

class sanity.checks.celery.TestCelery(methodName='runTest')[source]¶
test_0_init()[source]¶

Test the initialization of the test suite by retrieving and printing the celery stats.

test_1_celery_imports()[source]¶

Let’s make sure that we can import all of the celery imports defined in settings.CELERY_IMPORTS.

test_2_talk_to_the_rabbitmq_server()[source]¶

Verify that we can connect to and authenticate against the RabbitMQ server using Django’s BROKER settings.

test_3_verify_that_there_is_at_least_one_celeryd_worker_running()[source]¶

Check to see if there is at least one celery worker running to process tasks.

test_4_source_code_of_celery_workers()[source]¶

Make sure that the celery workers are running the correct code by verifying that the code in the current directory matches the code that the celery workers are running.

test_5_celery_queues_in_settings_equal_queues_being_serviced_by_celery_workers()[source]¶

Verify that all queues defined in Django settings are being serviced by a celery worker.

test_6_send_a_message_to_every_queue()[source]¶

Send a message to every queue configured in Django settings.

test_7_celerybeat()[source]¶

Test Celery Beat by checking to see if a specific task has executed within the last 5 seconds.

test_8_celery_logs()[source]¶

Test celery logs by writing ‘Sanity Check’ to each log.

sanity.checks.solr

test_solr_equality()[source]¶

Test equality.

Mock Solr test to ensure that 1 + 1 always equals 2. Let’s see what happens.
